commentBody: Incredibly easy, skipped over the theme entirely. New PB for me.
My time was 35% faster than my Tuesday average, so I'd say this was one of the easiest Tuesdays in recent memory.

Today the timer says I solved this puzzle in 2 minutes, 27 seconds.

I cannot even type fast enough to fill in the boxes with random letters that fast.
That was pretty quick! Liked the theme, thought it was clever.
New record and quickest solve ever for me!

Fun but easy Tuesday, more like a Monday.  Might have been a PB except one time I solved a puzzle when I was off Wifi and when I got back on Wifi it gave me credit for a 2 minute solve which is now my "Record".

Very good clues though.
All-time best time for me on this one, 6:19. Even beat my best Monday time
Very nice puzzle. I would have preferred to see it next Monday. Doing yesterday's puzzle again a la Groundhog Day might have taken me longer than doing this one.

Like others here, I ended up beating my personal best on this one, faster than my fastest Monday even. 

I'm curious though, could someone explain the "You win! I give up!" clue? I must be missing a reference here and Google is not helpful.
I'm sorry for your losses in the LA fires Nate, but very happy you've found resilience.  Thanks for the puzzle, I hope there will be more.
Thanks, Nate, for some puzzling joy today! Blessings on your new home‚Äîmay there be many good things ahead for you and your loved ones.
We had our new personal best here, went under four minutes. It was fun!

That puzzle was great, Nate! Flew through it fast and got a new world record! I enjoyed this one more than yesterday's. Keep it up! :)




[Word of the Day: 12D]
Like everyone else, this was definitely a Monday in disguise. Got it in under 4.

A fairly diverse group of voices inside the words/phrases. Elvis was a truly great singer in his youth. Those Chess recordings, man, he was FIRE. And Adele has a great set of lungs. I love it when she shifts into top gear. T Pain with his auto-tune is a little hard to take, but as far as "voices" go his is extremely recognizable even if it isn't organically his own. And Kesha, formerly Ke$ha, while I don't go for her music I've kept tabs on her and find her immensely relatable, even if I have nothing in common with her: she was extremely hardworking as a musician and songwriter from early on, and her work ethic and ability to keep changing shape and keep putting out albums, podcasts, writing songs, collaborating, doing benefits, tours, specials, while getting sued by this person or that studio, while doing all the rash and ill advised things stars of her ilk do, is a source of admiration and inspiration for me: what a dynamo. Still I'd have liked a few more voices to have been jammed into this grid, like maybe six or eight total. A foursome feels a little lonely. 

Good to see some ancillary voices here, in Eagle (as in Joe Walsh, Don Henley, et al.) -- all originally recruited by Linda Ronstadt to be her traveling band, and all blessed with good outside voices. Been thinking about their no. 1 hit "Lyin' Eyes" recently. Wonder why? And "Smile" - Brian Wilson's late masterpiece.  And The Strokes, who, having listened to it, can forget Julian Casablancas singing on This Is It?

Thanks Nate, terribly sorry about your home, but wonderful you‚Äôve moved to a new one.  Wish you all the best fortune there.

Juliana, often the clues and answers cause me to hear and recall memories‚Ä¶ today it was 39D and Sister Mary Elephant of Our Lady of 115th Street.  Back in 1972 we‚Äôd sit around on somebody‚Äôs living room at all listen together.  From today‚Äôs perspective, when everybody lives and listens in their own little pods, 1972 feels a warm, happy memory to me.

So sorry about your loss, Nate - and congratulations on the new home!

Like others, this was a super quick one for me, shaved a full minute off my previous Tuesday PB, and came within a few seconds on my record for Mondays.
To be pedantic, there are branches of mathematics where 0^0 is indeterminate, not equal to 1. The clue is probably still fine, since it does equal 1 in many common mathematical contexts.

Question for all you record breaking solvers: are you doing the puzzle on a computer, iPad, phone or do you print it and set your timer?  

I'm impressed that you solve the puzzle so quickly (even people who report 6 minutes is pretty amazing and way faster than I could ever finish) and while I don't currently care about how long it takes me, I may become more enthralled by my times as I get more gold stars. 

I personally solve it on my phone because it's more comfortable holding my phone than using my iPad.   I do appreciate printing it out so I can see more than one clue at a time- like it is on the computer. I haven't tried solving it on my phone using the three bars mode because I enjoy seeing the entire grid. 

Just curious....


Nate, I enjoyed your puzzle and sorry for your loss. I really enjoyed 28A (magazine for small screen since 1953) and I didn't need help from my wife with 22a (Shakespeare clue) because I solved it with the crosses. 

Written from my phone so please excuse typos

Dear Nate, my household and I were on fire with your crossword tonight, but in a good way. Tunnel vision slowed us down but we still came within 18 seconds of our best Tuesday time every. My puzzle-solving prodigy of a daughter was moved to tears by your constructor's note. Thanks for making this small piece of our daily routine such a pleasure tonight. All the best to you and your husband as you settle in and keep marching down the pathway of recovery!

Not a PB but 5:23 under my average. Took a few false starts but then flew through it. As a teacher I appreciated EYESONME my brain was reading 1 2 3‚Ä¶, INSIDE VOICES. My 3rd grade teacher was tunnel blind. Interesting puzzle

Nate this was a very enjoyable puzzle, clever theme. I‚Äôm sorry to hear about your home.
In another of those funny coincidences my nephew who is visiting from Israel just today asked me about this idiom and where it came from; I had no idea of course, another one of those funny things that came into the vocabulary whose origin is unknown (at least as far as I could research)
When I was done, I looked to see if there would also be a voice inside the revealer. I assume it's unintentional, but I smiled to see DEVO. Whip it good!
A fun puzzle and an incredibly poignant constructors message. Wishing you all the joy in your new home, and know that you brought me joy with this solve today.

Wow, Nate. Sorry to hear that you lost your home last year. We knew several people that lost their homes during that time üò¢ So glad to hear you have found a new home. As for the puzzle, it was truly on my wavelength. I hadn‚Äôt thought about TV GUIDE in years! I liked the variety of music artists for INSIDE VOICES. 
Thank you, Nate. Looking forward to more from you.

All of these _‚Äùfinished in X time‚Äù_ comments remind me of one particular classmate in college‚Ä¶

Who would sit in the first row of the lecture hall and upon receipt of his graded exam audibly proclaim (with performative dismay) how close indeed the score was to being 100%.

This was followed, without fail, by a furtive glance backwards to the rest of the class.

I certainly don‚Äôt mean to imply the commenters herein are anywhere near as insufferable though ;-)

Hit my personal best yesterday with 6:41, and I was 42 seconds away from doing it again today! It‚Äôs taken me years of solving daily to get here (since 2022), but it‚Äôs so fun to fly through a puzzle! FYI, I solve on my iPhone, and I would be faster if my fingers would hit the right letters!

I enjoyed seeing WHAM-O (16A) in the puzzle. Also, my high school team, the SUNS (3D), made an appearance. Fun puzzle!

userLocation: no longer writing like E. E. Cummings
commentBody:
First time the constructor notes made me swallow my review of the puzzle.
Had nothing BAD to say...
Still...
New experience.
Sorry about your house.

Quicker solve than Monday‚Äôs, but still satisfying. And sometimes it‚Äôs good to have an easy early week puzzle, to get those muscles flexed for the Friday/ Saturday workout. 

Congratulations on rising from the ashes, Nate. I hope you use that Phoenix energy to build a triumphant new life‚Ä¶ and hopefully some more awesome puzzles.

Quick one today, though not approaching any records for me, as I don't really try to beat my best times, and just enjoy the process. 

Given the Constructor Notes, I find it a tad ironic that the puzzle contains not only FIRE, but BURNT; OVENS; and OWNERS REGRET. I'm glad to hear that times are better, and that the important things (yourself and your husband) made it out safely and that you are getting re-established.

Fun puzzle, seeing the singers within the theme answers made me SMILE. Thanks, Nick!
I‚Äôm so glad you and your family are safe, Nate. Love the puzzle, looking forward to more.

Dear Nate, 
Thank you for a lovely puzzle, which did indeed give me joy.

I am so sorry to hear about your losses in the fire, and am hoping that you continue recovering from that trauma and finding new joys.
Loved this puzzle, Nate.  It‚Äôs so satisfying to watch all the answers cascade like dominoes.  I‚Äôm wishing you many more joys in the future.

That's the first time the constructor's notes have made me tear up. Writing from Minneapolis, the message about joy returning fully someday really hit me. Thank you for that. I wish you continued recovery and more joy this year.
This was so enjoyable. Thank you, Nate. I‚Äôm so sorry for your loss. May you and your husband continue to heal and discover many joys in your new home. Very best wishes.

This was one of my quickest Tuesday solves, faster than many Mondays. The theme was fine, but I don't quite get what an INSIDE VOICE is. Is it how you speak inside, as opposed to, say, shouting at a playground?

Dunno about the US but over here children - and adults - are not encouraged but required to keep quiet at libraries, and even whispering is frowned upon.

TOTES reminded me how surprised I was for decades each and every time I saw American shopping bags in films and on TV - made of paper and without handles üòÆ Especially the latter seemed so alien, and so inconvenient! Every time I saw them I thought: How do you carry several of those home? And sure enough, struggling with shopping bags has become an American TV trope, hasn't it?

It's not like our alternative was perfect, mind you - our shopping bags might have had handles, but they were plastic, and they contributed to pollution. These days single-use plastic shopping bags have been legally banned though, and we all use totes.

Sturdy, thick, plastic bags in bright colors, with logos and text in English, German or French, were smuggked into Poland from the West, and people considered them luxurious goods in the 1970s, 1980s, and early 1990s. We called them "reklam√≥wki", literally "the things with the ads". People usually had only a few of them, if not just one, and it was a sad day when they finally tore.

Probably one of my fastest Tuesday solves-- probably quicker than my quickest Monday! The pizzeria clue brought me back to one of my favorite pizza places in my area. I can't wait for when it's warmer so that I can enjoy the outdoor seating again.
Breezy as into 30 days with nearly 30 mins average. 49 D reminded me of that great ‚Äúit‚Äôs beets!‚Äù sketch guesting Jeff Goldblum on Portlandia.
Got a new personal best time for Tuesday with this one
Thanks for such an enjoyable puzzle, Nate. Every best wish to you and yours as your new home comes takes shape.

Very enjoyable puzzle,

Surely, I can't be the only one who put GRADELEVEN for 30D

65 Across is technically wrong. Zero raised to the zeroth power is undefined and not ONE. This is one of the considerations that leads to the concept of limits, and later on, differential calculus. Similarly, infinity raised to the zeroth power is also undefined.

Parading my ignorance: I was curious about IAGO and wondered idly if Shakespeare had made the name up. How embarrassing! It is cognate with the Cornish name Jago and with Jacob and Spanish Diego (hence Santiago! -- why did I not think of this?) and was the name of a string of kings of Gwynedd (in Wales) hundreds of years before Shakespeare.  

Wikipedia mentions that there have been a bunch of soccer players called Iago, and says it was the pen name of Britain's first and longest-serving Prime Minister Robert Walpole.

My favourite line from Iago in Shakespeare's Othello was the one that surprised me most, because it contains a phrase that I had assumed was modern fratboy slang, when he tells Brabantio:

"I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter
and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs."

Who knew?

Perfectly pleasant. 
I thought I was going to be able to solve this one with no look-ups, something I've only done once, I think. But I don't know Daytona and had LASCAR, A QUOTE and LATE - all seemed really logical! Although I know Americans spell it NITE, it's not familiar enough to me to use it. 

I don't know TPAIN or KESHA so didn't really follow up on the theme. Never seen a stick of butter!

New record time for Tuesday - MAV and HBO were the only ones I couldn't immediately put in as I romped through. Not sure the revealer is really common enough to be the basis of a satisfying theme, but it wasn't necessary anyway, I just noticed the singers in some entries as I went. Fun new experience not to get stuck somwhere during the solve!
*furtive glance backwards*
Thanks Nate!
Wow. A really enjoyable puzzle made poignant by the constructor‚Äôs notes. I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôve finally found a new home to hopefully regain the joy you felt when you made this grid.
Aaaay! My best time ever, not just Tuesday, but across the board. (4:52)
It turns out ‚Äúisaidso‚Äù has the same number of letters as BECAUSE.
A really nice and fun puzzle to start my Tuesday. Thank you Nate! And may the joy be with you.
Today is my Tuesday best! Very happy with this puzzle.

Long time solver and lurker here, first-time poster, pushed into my first ever comment by the thrill of achieving my all-time PB for any day of the week today: 3:47!

Just one of those days where almost every answer I put in on the first run turned out to be the correct one, requiring basically no changes at the end. Great theme and great early week puzzle!

My thoughts go out to Nate for what must have been a horrifically challenging year.
The number of record and very-low solving times is striking because this grid has one column more than usual.

Maybe I have trust issues, but I think NOTHING is only one of many suspicious answers in this puzzle to the innocent question ‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù :
SMILE
HAHA
THAT
FIRE
HEXES
TVGUIDE (because, c‚Äômon, does anyone, really?)
SOLVINGAPUZZLEINUNDER4MINUTES (because, ditto)

Nate, that you submitted this puzzle one day before the tragic fire ‚Äì what an illustration of how fortunes can change in an eyeblink.  My heart goes out to you and your husband, and may the healing continue.  Your story made me stop, really stop, and think about being more grateful about what I have as opposed to what I wish I had.  Thank you for that!

Nate,
Rarely do I wish I'd read the 
constructor's note *before*I solved.

The whimsy of this puzzle
against the backdrop of your ensuing year
are a sobering, tragic, and 
ultimately somewhat hopeful image.

So happy to think of you
arranging your new home,
with all the promise, potential,
and endurance it represents.

Thank you for sharing your puzzle
and your story.
Record Tuesday lfgggg
Wonderful Puzzle‚Ä¶fun solve without google‚Ä¶sending so many Blessings to this constructor and family after such a rocky 2025!‚ô•Ô∏èü¶ãü´∂üèªüëè

My favorite answer is INSIDE VOICES, which threw me back into elementary school, where teachers admonished us to use them as we walked in a line to the library, and if one of us spoke too loud while there, the teacher would sternly repeat the phrase.

Then I fondly flashed on ‚Äì actually saw in my mind‚Äôs eye -- the two elementary school teachers I adored.

That was followed by vivid elementary school memories, such as in second grade, when my teacher and another teacher were flirting. All the kids tittered about it, and I was proud to be chosen to relay her love notes to him.  

Crosswords, they wake things up, no?

In today‚Äôs puzzle, I like how the circled singers connect both words of two-word phrases rather than being simply embedded in one of the words.  I like the cross of IAGO and the homophone of ‚Äúvain‚Äù.  I also like the abutting of high and low art with SONATA and SMUT.

So, Nate, your puzzle was simply a lovely interlude beautifying my day.  Thank you!

A fun blast through a Tuesday. I usually don't like the quoted clues (possibly because I'm bad at them), but I thought IQUOTE today was a nice one (that I only got from the QU after a first pass).

I forgot to go back and look at the circled letters, but I don't think I'd have connected the inside voices thing. I think I'd have wasted quite a lot of time trying to figure out a connection between those four.t
Didn‚Äôt even need the downs. I think this might have been the easiest Tuesday I‚Äôve encountered.
This was a fun puzzle. Thanks, Nate. Wishing you and your husband complete recovery on all levels. Peace to y‚Äôall. Have a great Tuesday.
Two days in a row of quick solves, amazing.  But held up by the seemingly ever present typo as the "congrats" screen didn't pop up right away.  Had typed TRMVOR instead of TREVOR!

The theme seemed fine and the fill was solid enough. But the cluing ... is there a level even lower than Monday-level? Cause this one reached it. 

C'mon. This is Tuesday. And the New York Times puzzle!

Fun one.

Bit of a natick with WHAMO and OHSO but otherwise a smooth process. 

Happy Tuesday

Kramer: What's today?

Newman: It's Thursday.

Kramer: Really? Feels like Tuesday.

Newman: Tuesday has no feel. Monday has a feel, Friday has a feel, Sunday has a feel....

Kramer: I feel Tuesday and Wednesday...

Based on the many PRs for Tuesday (including my own) and even PRs for any day, I have to wonder if the editors switched yesterday‚Äôs puzzle with today‚Äôs, just so yesterday‚Äôs would run on GHD. 
Not a slight toward either constructor - both were enjoyable, IMO.
Huh. Well. I love a good challenge, but sometimes an easy win is just the thing needed to kick off the day. Thank you, creator. Cheers.
So glad that acceptance of this puzzle brought a lift of spirits to you, Nate. The puzzle was very enjoyable to solve. Best wishes for a better year in your new home.
Finished skimming the comments in PB time!
Fun quick solve. My new PR for a Tuesday.
This was the easy victory I needed today. Fun puzzle and now I‚Äôm hungry for shake shack and pizza

Well, that solve sure was FAST.
But I'm not furious about it! 
I wouldn't even mind a sequel.
Or eleven** of them, even.


**I checked.  They've actually made that many Fast and Furious films!!

OoooooKay!  Of course I knew ELVIS, and I've heard of ADELE.  
I had to revise SOLE at 34A, but other than that, this went quickly.
Nate Cardin...hmm.  A parent, a teacher, or both?  

I've never seen a SHAKE SHACK...?California chain?  Not that it matters; if I'm going to eat out, it won't be at a burger joint.  

Springerle update:  five dozen cookies in the freezer.  A number of them don't have the perfect impressions I wanted, but oh well.  Might have to re-assess this "hobby"--does my passion for anise flavor outweigh the struggle?  I could, after all, just use David Connell's wonderful recipe for plain anise cookies...

Oh, the puzzle--the crossword one!  Over too soon, but spanning the years of WHAM-O and ELVIS to modern ACER and KESHA.  Well done.
Thanks.
Curious about the term ‚Äòstandard dice‚Äô?

Not to sound like a broken record, but I too would like to join the chorus of those who broke records today.  Now, who else is going to volunteer to help clean up all those nasty, sharp shards of broken records littering the floor?  What a mess!  OUCH!
Thank you, Nate, for a very fun and clever Tuesday solve! I wish you and your husband all the best as you settle in to your new home -- may all your INSIDE (and outside) VOICES be happy ones!

The constructor notes for this one are amazing! Congrats on your new home and thank you for a lovely Tuesday morning! Both the puzzle and the notes are some of the many reasons why I do the crossword.

Nate, thanks for a fun (quick!) Tuesday. Your constructor notes made my heart ache. In northern CA we are all too familiar with wildfire devastation. We know many who lost everything here and in LA. Your notes really capture the depth of that loss and the ongoing trauma of recovery. I hope you and your husband find much happiness and joy in your new home. When you feel up to it, please send more puzzles.

Nate, like many others I was moved by your experiences of the last year. I can hardly imagine what that turmoil must have been like.  Your puzzle was a delight to solve, with the memories it brought up of elementary classes and teachers, ‚Äúsaying uncle,‚Äù tossing frisbees, hearing Elvis as a teenager, etc. Solving these puzzles has become more than mental exercise‚Ä¶ it is all about our shared humanity. Thank you for being part of that. 
Best wishes on your continuing healing journey.
The weather VANE on our boat house is shaped like a great blue heron, actually. It can be confusing when the genuine article decides to sit up there.
Could have been a Monday puzzle. It often takes mo more time for  Tuesday puzzles.

Fun one today,  and for those looking to challenge yourself on the easier solves,  try solving by only doing across clues, not looking at any down clues. Today was the first time I was able to do it on a Tuesday puzzle.  :)

Definitely quick for me -- but not faster than Monday, even though I had to search for a typo yesterday. Still not a Tuesday PR, but within 20 seconds. But this one was easy for pretty much everyone according to XWSTATS, with an astonishing 98 percent finishing faster than their average time. I couldn't get a couple of the long across entries on the first pass, which meant I had to use a lot of the down entries to finish.

In regards to the challenge or lack of challenge to this puzzle‚ÄîI usually find Mondays and Tuesdays so easy it‚Äôs hard for me to gauge what‚Äôs unusually easy or not‚Äîif it‚Äôs chewier I notice but not the other way around. I will say I was struck by ‚ÄúE on a compass‚Äù. There‚Äôs easy and then there 3rd grade easy. I have to say you‚Äôd think that there‚Äôs some other clue the editors could have come up with that‚Äôs Monday or Tuesday worthy that‚Äôs better than that!

To the constructor: so very sorry about the loss of your home. I was familiar with many of the terms except TP---- a stumper for me. I had no idea what it meant and will check it later. Thank you for this  fun puzzle.

Record Tuesday time on this one. Thanks for the birthday present! (Turned 56 today, and feeling every bit of it.)

Many condolences to the constructor for losing your home in the fires.

Fun, breezy puzzle. Thanks, Nate!

Now to go look up these singers TPAIN and KESHA.
I'll read the comments and see if there are any exemplary music links recommended.

Busy day - late to the party. Nice Tuesday puzzle. Bit of a workout for me with a couple of complete unknowns (to me). It took a while to tumble to the theme but that was a nice moment when I finally got it. 

Answer history search today was inspired by SPEEDO. Did a search for... MREARL (or) MISTEREARL. Nope - neither of those was ever in a puzzle. And... much to my surprise, even the string of letters REALNAME (in the singular) was only in one puzzle. Some of you will get that. 

I'm done. 

....
My first puzzle without a single lookup, and a new best time!

Reading through a good portion of clues, I had no idea what the answers were. After I got started, I was able to use some of the letters to formulate the answers I needed. This is one of the rare puzzles where I didn‚Äôt have to look at the answer key. The theme was very clever, as I enjoyed finding the names of famous singers in the circles boxes. Once I got going this was an extremely easy and enjoyable puzzle.
Set a PR, my second this week, and yet didn't get the theme til I read this column!
Seemed like a Monday. EZ

Any NYT puzzle that opens with NASCAR, with an Elvis chaser, has high potential (love that show, BTW). 

So relieved that yesterday's highly applauded Donald stench was countered with today's Biden burnt. Can't understand why I didn't get the San Jose strut though. Need to check my spelling... hmmm. There is hope after all.

Can't quite get my head around the circled responses being inside voices. Inside of what? Neither Elvis or TPain speak to me. Maybe my retirement years have given me chunnelvision, who knows. Maybe the answer is 31A.
Excellent puzzle Nate. Clearly, you are a talented constructor, and a very, thoughtful & resilient individual. Kudos!

As a newbie crossword-er I really enjoyed this one! Solved in about 14 minutes, only had to look up Wham-O because I'm not American and wasn't sure that's the correct name. Otherwise a good beginners puzzle, and I appreciate it :-)
Finished in 3:15, 4 seconds off my PR! If I wasn't trying to eat my lunch at the same time I could have hit a new best

Today's xwstats.com stats shows that this was an exceptionally easy Tuesday puzzle:

Those 2% must have taken a phone call--or a nap--in the middle of their solve.
One of my fastest Tuesdays!
very enjoyable :) sometimes an easier puzzle is refreshing

Can we talk about the fact that ICEE appears nearly every week (sometimes more than once a week), and no one has actually had or seen an ICEE in over 30 years?  It‚Äôs one of those words like ORE and EPEE that really don‚Äôt come up outside of NYT crossword puzzles. You can go your entire life probably never saying, writing, or thinking about such words, unless you do a crossword puzzle, in which case you must think about them regularly.

With love,
Gooch Johnson
Can someone PLEASE fix the pdf of the Saturday Jan 31 puzzle? It does not print. Just a blank screen. Thanks!
Clean, elegant, fun. Thanks, Nate.
Bit easy even for a Tuesday.
4:22 today, almost a new pr

Today wasn't just my fastest Tuesday time, it was my fastest puzzle ever - 10:09! I believe I'll break the 10 min barrier at some point, but I don't really solve for time. I always look at the down clues when my across clue will solve if I haven't seen them yet for example. Quick and easy fun puzzle which I needed with this head cold.
Fun, easy puzzle. Now... any number except 0 itself -- raised to 0   = 1.

Not a blistering pace for me today, although I never solve at a blistering pace, but I am pleased that this is the first puzzle I've successfully solved with only the across clues! And somehow nearly 40% faster than my average!

I very much enjoyed the theme, and even made sure to read all the down clues after I finished it ^-^

I enjoyed this quick and fun puzzle.  It's nice to have a relaxing puzzle to remind me I do have a brain that works, especially after questioning that over the weekend!  :-)  And after a day spent wrangling kids who may or may not particularly want to do what I need them to do!  

Having seen my parents, then years later my sister and her family, go through the aftermath of a house fire, my heart goes out to Nate and his husband.  The joy will return to your life, it takes time.  Keep plugging away, friends.  I look forward to seeing your name on another puzzle in the future.
New Tuesday record at 2:38!! And yes, I see everyone else saying how easy this one was ‚Äî but considering this is even 6 seconds faster than my Monday record, I‚Äôll take the win :)

@Dave K.

I guess it was easy; my time was 30% less than average.  I did not intentionally skip the theme. It's just that I finished the puzzle without realizing what it was.
@Dan Yeah the clock is often whack. All of my best times are impossible.

@Chris
I have a record of 5:21 for a Saturday!  Not sure how that happened, since my average is about 40 minutes.  That's OK.  I don't pay a lot of attention to times.  But I do laugh a little when I see that 5:21...
@Kyle me too got 8:12, just missed beating my all time Monday best by 5 secs ü•≤

@Barry Ancona
Actually, Tuesday's puzzle took me 26 sec longer than Monday's, in keeping with the progressive difficulty of the week. Still, this was a Tuesday best time for me.

@Barry Ancona Speaking of Groundhog Day, here's an anecdote. Today at Bible Study, I used a joke of sorts from yesterday's comments. It had to do with a little girl's answer to her pastor's question regarding the significance of Easter. The one where she said, " Jesus died for our sins on the cross, then was put in a tomb, with a rock across the opening, when he came out, he saw his shadow, and went back in, because there was going to be six more weeks of winter. :)

@Norbr ‚Äúsay uncle‚Äù is a demand to concede, usually when wrestling or fighting in general. Probably very old slang (like I am)
L

@Norbr

It's a bit of slightly dated US slang.  When someone (a child, usually) wants to give up in a fight or other physical challenge, he (and it's usually he) cries, "UNCLE."

@Norbr
It's an idiom in North American schoolyard for the one having the upper hand in a fight (and often a headlock on the opponent) to demand "Say Uncle!". 

If the defeated person says "Uncle", the fight is over. If they refuse, conflict continues. 

I don't know the history or origins, but it was both ancient, and common, when I was in school in the 1960s.

@Norbr I replied as quickly as I could, but was still 4th. But since then I've realized the source of your confusion. It's the missing "say". Google "say UNCLE" instead of just UNCLE, and you'll find out lots more about it. Or just go here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Say_Uncle
@Norbr. Kipling used ‚Äúsay UNCLE‚Äù with this meaning in 1899. (Stalky & CoJ, so the phrase is more global in usage than mentioned here.

@Patrick J. Do you have the Kipling quote, or a pointer to it? Because in the project Gutenberg text of the book, those two words don't appear next to each other: https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/3006 I searched the plain text version, and while there's many mentions of UNCLE Stalky, I didn't find any instance of "say UNCLE". But just for fun: - a clip from "A Christmas Story": https://youtu.be/Z2l6RnWM2tU?si=oC3eB8khdhqUydF8 - and one from "South Park": https://youtu.be/UMRy1CmxvMY?si=wLMXkKOJlYVt5yWW

@Patrick J. OK, I went hunting and found an academic journal article about this. Start here: https://daily.jstor.org/what-the-folk-the-charming-yet-totally-malappropriate-story-of-words/ This is the linguistics blog from the JSTOR site and the discussion about uncle is 1/3 of the way down. If you use the link there, you can access the original article. The article suggests that 'uncle' is a corruption of Irish 'anacul', meaning mercy or quarter (as in 'give quarter'). Warning: this link is catnip for wordies. The journal you're sent to has tons of fascinating stuff!

@john ezra 

Yes and Wham! could be included in your list, and a single Car.

@sonnel
I'd forgotten Sister Mary Elephant!  Now I'm laughing to myself remembering.  Thanks for that!

@DW or as she would primly say after yelling 
"Shut up!": 
"Thank You"

I can still hear it clear as day.
@Nick if you look up blackpenredpen on YouTube, he has lots of insightful videos on the subject.

@_chs_
I solve on an iPhone. It‚Äôs taken me years to get into the single digits on early week puzzles. I would say I‚Äôm a Tuesday solver, meaning (according to my definition) I can generally solve the Monday and Tuesday puzzles without lookups.

@_chs_

Typing on a PC is much faster than on a phone. My Monday phone record is 6 minutes, but I'm pretty sure it'd be 4 or less on a PC. I don't care about solving times though and I prefer the comfort of solving on my phone, on the sofa or in bed.

@_chs_ I normally solve on my phone, but I currently have to use my iPad. I‚Äôm much slower on the iPad. I am still usually faster than my average time. (My average times include hundreds of archived puzzles from the 90s. I‚Äôm much slower at those.) 

I‚Äôm actually your opposite in that one of the reasons I prefer the phone is because you only see one clue at a time. On the iPad the screen is so busy that I struggle to remember where I should be looking.

@Andrzej

And I'm looking into graves with wifi!

@Francis

Why don't you create a fund in your will, tasked in perpetuity with maintaining an internet access point at your grave, connected to the mobile network?

@mnemonica

When that song came out I was supervising a group of student workers in a college bookstore. When we were in the process of sending unsold texts back to the publisher and "Whip It" played on the radio, my crew would sing it out loud, substituting "ship" for "whip."
@mnemonica -- Oh, great catch!

@Mishlev

I would like to say without fear of contradiction by friend or foe, that I am, at the very least, that insufferable.

@Mishlev that scenario is a tee-up for a prepared snappy comeback. Did no-one ever bite?

"Never mind, you'll be a total dork one day."
"Rats! So close to someone caring."
"Too bad. I'll go cancel the parade."
@Mishlev If I PR on a puzzle, I just share that fact, rather than the time itself. All that matters is how I've done relative to my previous efforts.

@Francis

It sure is over here - we still have some traditional cobblers, and there are specialist shops that resole trekking and climbing shoes with highest quality materials, including vibram. Sadly, most people just throw away shoes rather than repair them. 

The Western shopping bag thing was about scarcity rather than about frugality, as such. Stuff from the West was sought after but hard to get. 

There were so few single-use things in my 1980s childhood! Throw-away culture has turned out to be one of the few changes for the worse brought about by market economy.
@Andrzej correct, it‚Äôs inside voices as opposed to shouting outside, not talking to the voices inside.

@Francis
Starving student stories seem like a joke until you've lived it.  Shoes? I have narrow feet, and style was never an issue; it was always cost, and I did indeed always get them repaired. 

Studying for lit finals was a challenge, because each book had to be sold for cash to buy the next one.

Ever been a smoker? I was then, and we were always looking for "snipes." The best place was the sand filled ashtray at the library door, because the cigs were often almost whole, and never crushed.  Eeew, I can't imagine doing that now, but I did it then. (Thankfully, I was able to quit the habit about 40 years ago. Excruciating, as if I had lost my dearest friend, but so worth it.)

@SBK

The volume at which people carry on cell conversations wherever they happen to be seems bizarre.  People walk past our house speaking louder than if they were talking to someone walking next to them, completely oblivious to who is hearing their conversation.  I'm tempted to lean out the door and yell, "Tell them I said hello!"

@Andrzej It is such an American TV trope that I complain at the TV every time I see it. Still no idea whether it's real or not, though my theory is that Americans in the suburbs have to drive everywhere so really all they need is a way to get grocery items from the trolley (shopping cart) to the car and from the car to the house. The car to the house section being the inevitable stumbling block of any American TV housewife requiring a fortunate/unfortunate meeting with a hero/villain on the street.

But I mean, how hard is it to put a couple of handles on your paper bag?

Andrzej,
We walk here ... and shop with our own totes. I haven't been in a car since this summer (when I was in the Midwest).

@Barry Ancona

It was 13-15 years ago, and I'm generally not known for not exaggerating üòÑ

@Tim
Paper grocery bags have had handles on them for 30 years. I dont care for plastic bags but the rationale is that many more can be bulk transported than paper, so thay save transportation costs.

@Andrzej

Around here, most people started using reusable totes once the markets started charging for disposable bags. Not much, but enough to tweak the conscience.
@Hanson I figured as much, which makes it all the more annoying that TV shows refuse to put the handles on!

@Warren

Over here shops can't an't sell disposable bags, and they are required to replace for free the multiple-use bags they sell. The idea is that people won't just throw away a torn bag but exchange it for a new one, and the supermarket will have the old ones properly recycled. I have no idea how well all this works in practice. Most people just use their own, sturdy totes. As recently as 10 years ago almost everybody used disposable bags, so we've made progress.

@duchiris Also a long-ago smoker, I don't think I ever got a "snipe" from a public ashtray but I might have found one in one of my own --like in the car. We had a store that sold single cigarettes. That was great for me while I was trying to quit. (That didn't last long, though--it's not allowed by law.) Smoking is so bad. When I finally quit, it was all uphill. I didn't even think about it after three days. I could breathe better and became more active. I would walk five or six miles and then started jogging (in my thirties.) I lost twenty pounds eventually and was thin for the first time in my life. I've come to believe that smoking isn't even addictive. To be addictive, one of the qualities of a substance is that you have withdrawal symptoms when you stop. Like when you quit using caffeine, you might get a withdrawal headache. When you quit alcohol, there are withdrawal symptoms, too. Serious ones. But quit smoking--and it's all better. From the Cleveland Clinic: "When you cut back or quit using nicotine-containing products, the lack of nicotine in your body can cause uncomfortable symptoms. But nicotine withdrawal isn‚Äôt harmful to your health. It fades over time as long as you stay nicotine-free." https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/21587-nicotine-withdrawal

@dutchiris

You were able to quit and you are still here.  My Dad couldn't, and he isn't.
@Andrzej at the counter in the library.... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bgxbx9HoGUw

@Andrzej

Yep, a few communities tried similar approaches over here, and I‚Äôm sure you can imagine the culture war results.  Charging something is at least better than charging nothing, as a zero charge (falsely signaling a zero resource cost) will almost always lead to over consumption, from a purely economic-efficiency point of view.

@McT
I'm sorry your Dad is no longer with you.  Quitting smoking is harder than anyone who hasn't been through it can imagine.  And like alcohol, the addiction is always there, waiting.

The tobacco industry did everything it could to suppress studies showing that nicotine addiction is on a par with heroin, in some cases more so, and early on they even promoted cigarettes as a healthy means for weight loss. Back when I was in college in the 1950's and 60's almost everyone I knew smoked cigarettes.  My craving finally ended when I became allergic even to ambient cigarette smoke.

Quitting was the best thing I ever did for my physical well being, and it made an extraordinary difference in my day-to-day life. No more chronic bronchitis (which had started at age 17!!), no more feeling cold all the time, better skin, more energy than I ever dreamed I had, myriad benefits were enormous once I was off them.

Years ago, when I quit, I couldn't even talk about it. When my husband stopped smoking and was waling about how terrible it was for him, and hadn't noticed that I had not had a cigarette for a week, I actually picked up a chair and threw it at the wall! He  was shocked, and we agreed to never talk about smoking again.

I was lucky to get though it. I'm sorry that your Dad was not.

@dutchiris
I will intervene, if I'm annoyed beyond bearing. I try a side-eye, then a shhhh,  but then I will launch a counteroffensive, responding to their remarks with 'helpful' suggestions and comments. Not often for me to be driven that far, but if I do this, it works. Either they quiet down or get up and change seats.

@Andrzej
Sadly, those stupid bags were entirely real. And they're back! As stores opt for paper over plastic (these days, an ecological choice), they have gone back to handleless paper. Why? Beats me.

@Andrzej
I lived in Hamburg, Germany in 2005-06 and still use 2 canvas shopping bags i bought there.  Stores didn't have free give-away bags at all.  But my two favorites are ones I got a drug store in Durban South Africa where we lived 2020-22.  They are sepia photos -- one a giraffe and one a rhino.

Our city in California, Palo Alto, banned one-use plastic bags from stores several years ago, and now the rest of the state is finally following suit.  But we were also one of the first places to ban smoking in public spaces -- over 40 years ago.  

I agree this puzzle was a little easy.  I did it in Monday time, and didn't really get the theme until after it was all done.  But I work at an elementary school where "One, two, three, eyes on me" and "Use your inside voices" are heard regularly.

commentBody:

I never heard of this meaning for 'snipe'. Do you know how it was derived?
@CH I absolutely did too!
@CH That was my one error too. I didn't read the crossing clue at the bottom until I got to it after failing to get the happy music.

@Prithwiraj

Yes, but zero is just one tiniest, infinitesimalist piece of the entirety of the real number line, so it's outvoted.

I jest, of course.  This clue/answer is just another wonderful example of the way that crosswords lead to fascinating conversations.

And infinitesimalist really is a word.  You don't have to check me on that.  Your can trust me.

@Prithwiraj

Infinity is not a number; it's only something that can be used as a limit or concept. Maybe you meant: The limit of x ^ 0 as x goes to infinity is undefined. (Which is news to me.)
@Francis funny, I've always spelled it infinitesimalest.

commentBody:
@Elbridge Gerry
Try telling that to aleph-one!

@Petrol
Yes interestingly Iago is straight from from "Saint Jacob" ("Sancti Iacobi" - "Sant Iaco"), which transformed into more common names like "(San) Diego" and "Thiago", moving the final consonant sound from saint to the beginning of the first name. Usually called Saint James in English, an apostle with a pretty wide variety of apparent names across languages.

commentBody:
@Petrol

I remember this image in high school driving me to read more Shakespeare.

@Francis

"Shakespeare was no prude!"

Don't tell @SBK

ü§£

(Sorry not sorry, I just had to)
@Petrol I didn't, thanks.

@Andrzej
Too late. 
In Canada you do at least one Shakespeare play a year in high school.  We covered the Scottish Play, Julius Caesar, As You Like It, Romeo and Juliet, and The Merchant of Venice (I think.) We memorized at least one speech per play (Tomorrow and tomorrow; Friends, Romans; Seven ages of Man; What light; and The quality of Mercy), all of which remain ensconced in my brain.  I don't say my 13-year-old self understood every pun and double entendre but we didn't skip anything.
Sadly, I doubt that either the memorization or the complete text would be the case today.

@SBK
I am eternally grateful that DeKalb County schools had an English program that was rigorous! In 8th-12th grades we read multiple Shakespeare plays, beginning with less challenging/shocking ones ...(Romeo +, Julius Caesar, Midsummer, Taming, Henry V, -)--with the darker ones such as MacB saved for latter years, when we also read plays by  Euripides and Sophocles.  It was all worthwhile, no matter what we later chose To Be....

@Mean Old Lady
I‚Äôm sure I have mentioned it before, but it bears repeating.  If any of this community have never been to, or perhaps never even heard of, the Stratford Festival in the lovely town of Stratford, Ontario, you must make it your business ‚Äî or pleasure, rather ‚Äî to put a visit there ‚Äî or even a sojourn ‚Äî on your bucket list (or start one with this at the top).  The Stratford Festival runs from mid-April to late October every year (and sometimes extends very popular plays into early December), putting on about a dozen plays across four stages with a repertory company of actors.  There are always three or four Shakespeare plays, along with a couple of musicals ‚Äî you must include any musical directed by the incomparably talented Donna Feore ‚Äî and specially commissioned works, as well as at least one play geared for a younger audience.  Occasionally, they have been able to attract internationally known actors like Maggie Smith and Brian Bedford to grace their stages.  (We have been making annual pilgrimages to the Stratford Festival for nearly 50 years and hope to continue doing so for another 20 more.)

@Al  in Pittsburgh

@Mean Old Lady Useless info you didn't ask for:  There was a restauranteur originally from St Louis who, among other brands, started Shake Shack.  In the 50's - 70s a very popular burger joint was Steak n Shake - that prominently advertised grinding daily in their own comissaries using steak cuts of beef.  And a long time local treasure was Ted Drewes' Frozen Custard.  Pretty sure Steak Shack is a tribute to the originator's childhood.

commentBody:

@Ace while on the topic, does anybody still call it an emoticon? For, I don't know, a decade maybe, it's been an emoji in my world.

@Avi Lieberman
Different things, different names.
This is an emoticon wink: 
;-)
This is an emoji wink:
üòâ
Emoticons are simpler to produce and rely on nothing but the standard character set. Anyone can create one.
Emojis depend on a specialized set of curated symbols. They must be vetted before entering the accepted set of transmissible illustrations. But they allow subtleties beyond the capacity of emoticons.
Here you go! https://www.nytimes.com/svc/crosswords/v2/puzzle/print/Jan3126.pdf
